source:
#set up variables like file location 

dataPath = 'abfss://synapsehackaton@asadatalakeimre2.dfs.core.windows.net/30tb/*/';
claimsPath = dataPath + 'Claim.ndjson';
observationPath = dataPath + 'Observation.ndjson';

#Claims output paths
outClaimsPath = 'abfss://bronze@asadatalakeimre2.dfs.core.windows.net/historic_data/Claim/'
outIncrementalClaimsPath = 'abfss://bronze@asadatalakeimre2.dfs.core.windows.net/incremental_data/Observation/'

#observations output path
outObservationsPath = 'abfss://bronze@asadatalakeimre2.dfs.core.windows.net/historic_data/Observation/'
outIncrementalObservationsPath = 'abfss://bronze@asadatalakeimre2.dfs.core.windows.net/incremental_data/Claim/'

# read the schema to be used from 2 individual json files, in order to avoid scanning all 20000 / 40000 files to be scanned twice
schemaClaimsPath = 'abfss://synapsehackaton@asadatalakeimre2.dfs.core.windows.net/30tb/000047ca-00c7-492b-bf65-740805144cd2/Claim.ndjson' 
schemaObservationPath = 'abfss://synapsehackaton@asadatalakeimre2.dfs.core.windows.net/30tb/000047ca-00c7-492b-bf65-740805144cd2/Observation.ndjson'
schemaClaims =  spark.read.option("multiline", "false").json(schemaClaimsPath).schema
schemaObservations =  spark.read.option("multiline", "false").json(schemaObservationPath).schema

#read the Claims files and filter on the relevant years for daily split / incremental data, then partition by year, month, day and write 
from pyspark.sql.functions import to_date, year, month, dayofmonth, col;
dfClaims = spark.read.option("multiline", "false").option("columnNameOfCorruptRecord", "corrupt").schema (schemaClaims).json(claimsPath);

#add partition columns
dfClaimsByDay = dfClaims.withColumn('year', substring('created', 1,4)).withColumn('month', substring('created', 6,2)).withColumn('day', substring('created', 9,2)).where(col('year') == "2021")

#write out the incremental data for Claims
#without repartitioning this leads to extremely small files 20 KByte) and a huge number of partitions (16910, same as number of input files)
#we will try coallesce it to number of executors we can get, which is 76
#this will result in a json file of apporximately 5-7 MBytes going forward
dfClaimsByDay.coalesce(76).write.option("multiline", "false").mode("overwrite").partitionBy ('year', 'month', 'day').json(outIncrementalClaimsPath)

#read the Observations files and filter on the relevant years for daily split / incremental data, then partition by year, month, day and write 
from pyspark.sql.functions import to_date, year, month, dayofmonth, substring, col;
dfObservations = spark.read.option("multiline", "false").option("columnNameOfCorruptRecord", "corrupt").schema (schemaObservations).json(observationPath);

#add partition columns
dfObservationsByDay = dfObservations.withColumn('year', substring('issued', 1,4)). \
    withColumn('month', substring('issued', 6,2)). \
    withColumn('day', substring('issued', 9,2)). \
    where(col('year') == "2021")


#write out the incremental data for Observations
#without repartitioning this leads to extremely small files 20 KByte) and a huge number of partitions (31856, same as number of input files)
#we will try coallesce it to number of executors we can get, which is 76
#this will result in a json file of approximately 8-12 MBytes going forward
dfObservationsByDay.coalesce(76).write.option("multiline", "false").mode("overwrite").partitionBy ('year', 'month', 'day').json(outIncrementalObservationsPath)
